title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: The interview was technical and expected. Hiring managers were very professional and capable. I would recommend to come prepared and be ready to be engaged in high-level and technical discussions.
Interview Questions: It was all technical stuff

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: About 1 week after submitting my application I received an email inviting me to schedule a phone screen interview. That interview took about 20 minutes and then I was requested to provide a code and writing sample. I am still waiting to hear back if I will continue further in the process.
Interview Questions: What is your coding experience?

title: Junior Data Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: First, there was a coding test with a few questions to test my Python skills. The interview was a one-on-one interview with technical questions, such as asking for the step-by-step process for one of my projects.
Interview Questions: Describe the steps you took for any project you completed recently.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: I went through a phone screening interview with HR, and then did a second interview with a researcher who would manage the internship. The interviews were short, 30 minutes each and asked typical behavioral questions and experience creating digital content. I never heard back.
Interview Questions: What is an accomplishment you're most proud of?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Mar 2023
Interview Descriptions: I applied online, received an email from a recruiter about 2 weeks later, and had an initial (20-30 min) phone screening about a week after that, with questions about my qualifications and why I'm interested in this position. About a week later I received an email to schedule a video call interview, and I spoke with 4 different employees with various positions, with a mix of behavioral questions and giving me a chance to ask them questions
Interview Questions: Describe a time when... (ex. you worked on a team, you communicated information, you had a tight deadline, etc.)

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Arlington, VA) in Mar 2023
Interview Descriptions: The interview process included a screening call with a recruiter and a hiring lead, a day-long interview with various team members, and a job talk. Each interviewer asked thoughtful and unique questions.
Interview Questions: What are your perspectives on the state of our field? What are scholars and practitioners doing well? What are scholars and practitioners missing? What are your ideas for moving the field forward?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Atlanta, GA) in Feb 2023
Interview Descriptions: Took a really long time to get back to me between each stage. Wasn't transparent. Had to follow up between interviews. Took 3 months total, without keeping me updated between stages.
Interview Questions: How do you feel about working in teams?

title: Research Scientist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: I had a first interview with HR which asked standard questions, then an interview with a team member which asked more in depth questions. Then I was to do a whole day of interviews with various team members and give a job talk. Honestly I was frustrated that I put in so much work not to receive an offer. I think they went with someone who had more technical experience, and I would have just rather they cut things off after the second interview rather than asking me to put so much time and effort into a whole day of interviews.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: I have not received a formal offer or rejection yet but I wanted to comment about the interview process. So far the process has taken 3 months. I was initially screened via phone call about 1 week after my application. Then I did not hear back for weeks after reaching out several times. I was contacted by a different recruiter about a month after my initial phone screening to do another phone screening.  A few weeks later I was invited to an interview with 2 senior researchers. I was asked standard questions about my skill set and research experience. I was told a final decision would be made in about a week and I should hear back. After a few weeks I was invited to an additional interview. I was told that although the center was interested, there were no job openings for the original team I interviewed with. The next interview was with one senior researcher and again answered standard interview questions. Again it has been a few weeks and I have not received a final decision after reaching out for an update. All interviewers were very nice and seemed to enjoy their jobs but the interview process is very off-putting.
Interview Questions: What data softwares do you have experience with?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: I was first interviewed by the HR person, who then set up a group interview with 2 senior researchers and 1 manager. They asked questions about my prior research expereince, project management, and data analysis.
Interview Questions: What is your experience with managing projects?

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Austin, TX) in Aug 2022
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process was straightforward. Contact from the recruiter asked about my resume and then set an interview with the team.
The team was looking for a SAS programmer. I have experience programming in R and Python. I talked about  R and python but the team had tailored technical questions in SAS and began asking questions on SAS. 
I'd told my recruiter that I have experience in other programming languages but not so much in SAS. I wish they had arranged the interview with the team with all of my information. 
The recruiter or the team didn't give me any information on what their team does in the beginning. But when I ask them, all they did was clean and merge data.
Interview Questions: Are you willing to learn SAS on hire?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was straightforward and relatively traditional. The questions were standard, and there was an opportunity to ask any questions that a candidate would have. No additional comments to make at this time.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Senior Industrial/Organizational (I/O) Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in May 2022
Interview Descriptions:
First round was HR phone screening, background-related questions and opportunity to explain how they fit the role.
Second round was a Teams meeting with the division managing director. Role-related competencies focused.
Third round was meetings with 7 people (interviewers were paired up and there were several Teams sessions). These interviews each appeared to have a different job-related theme and we talked about specific skills and experiences. Very conversational. Plus a 1 hour job talk/ presentation on a I/O subject of my choice, also on Teams.
Finally, a Teams meeting with area Vice President.
Interview Questions: Interview questions were on the whole focused on competencies for the role. I was also asked repeatedly about why I was interested in AIR and this role at AIR.

title: Data Scientist Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in May 2022
Interview Descriptions: Three stages to the interview process: first a take-home coding test which took roughly 2-3 hours, next a 30 minute phone interview, and lastly a three-round panel interview with 7 people total.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your prior research projects

title: Communications Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: Initial phone call with a recruiter. Then second phone call with the hiring manager. Then zoom interview with 5 team members separately (30 mins each). Received an offer about 2 weeks later.
Interview Questions: They asked a lot of scenario-based questions.  How do you keep yourself organized and what time management skills?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: It was a call with a recruiter that was basically to make sure I was interested in the role, then a one-on-one interview a week late. Finally, 3 consecutive one-on-one interviews, and I received an offer a week later.
Interview Questions: Talk about your quantitative experience.

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: I sent in an application with a resume and cover letter. The hiring manager reached out to me to set up a call. I had a phone screening with the hiring manager and then never heard back. They seemed optimistic, but probably chose someone with a more technical background.
Interview Questions: Common traditional and behavioral questions!

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: One initial screening  call by the recruiter, followed by a video call where I talked to the director of the team, and then I was told they would contact me for a third interview with a panel of people and then they ghosted me.
Interview Questions: How would you handle multiple tasks for different projects?

title: Human Resources Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Arlington, VA) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: The Recruiter called me and the interview was very smooth . But the sad part was the recruiter didn't back with the result of the interview. Inspite of me dropping a follow up email i didn't get any reply. Very unprofessional.
Interview Questions: Statistics Questions , Past Work experience.

title: Data Science Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Arlington, VA) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: Coding test, a one-on-one interview, and then an three round interview with several people. Both personal interviews contained technical questions and the final one contained more “tell me a time when” questions. Everyone was very personable and the process went pretty quickly, with only about a week or so between the two personal interviews.
Interview Questions: What are you learning right now?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: easy interview with basic research related questions. 1st round with HR and 2nd round with team members. HR mostly asks behavioral questions while in the 2nd round, they want to know your research interest. interviewers are super nice and friendly, they are dream colleagues.
Interview Questions: introduce yourself and your research interest

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Jan 2022
Interview Descriptions: Very quick turn around process. Contacted by recruiter days after I submitted application, interviewed two weeks later, job offer followed immediately afterwards. The research was previously familiar with my work — allowed for a very informal laid back interview. Felt that I was interviewing the team rather them interviewing me.
Interview Questions: What type of projects do you see yourself working on

title: Research Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: Sat through an all day interview and never hear back from them … interviewed with over 6 people for an entry level position. Some people were in person and some were over zoom
Interview Questions: Have you ever worked with an international team

title: Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: A phone screening was followed by the company providing transportation and lodging for the interview at their central office. A one-hour test was followed by a series of interviews in person and by phone with managers at several different levels.
Interview Questions: I was asked about my particular experience that was unusual in the field.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process went quite quickly. After submitting an application online, I was contacted for a phone interview a few days later. I was asked for a writing sample and scheduled for an interview the next week. I had two more back-to-back interviews, which I will admit that I did not feel that confident about. After a week or so, I reached out to one of the interviewers and my recruiter but neither responded. I tried reaching out one more time but never got a response. I understand getting ghosted early in the process, but it seems rude to go through three interviews and not get the courtesy of an email letting me know they were not moving forward.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your quantitative experience

title: Research Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: It was very smooth and friendly. They asked e about my research experiences and working experiences. They answered my questions patiently and completely. They tried to support me as well.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself and your research.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: 1 screening phone interview. Then 2 weeks later, 3 interviews by different team members back to back. Received an offer 4 days after interview. Recruitment team is very helpful & responsive
Interview Questions: Describe a time where you disagreed with a supervisor? What was the result?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: I did not interview with American Institutes for Research. I never heard back about my application, and could not find anyone to get in touch with to check in about my application.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Education Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: The interview process itself was smooth. The interviewers were nice and straightforward, and the materials that I needed for the programming part of the interview was sent before so that I could prepare. Positive experience overall
Interview Questions:
Tell me about yourself
Programming questions

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Jun 2021
Interview Descriptions:
The interview questions were very cookie cutter, and I felt that the interviewer didn't leave much space for me to show who I was. 
The interviewer unfortunately had very little concrete information about the position itself, so very few of my questions were answered. 
I left the interview feeling like the interviewer had very little idea of who I was as a person, which was frustrating.
Interview Questions:
What made you interested in this position? 
What do you hope to do in 5 years?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: Pretty straightforward. Recruiter sends email, does initial virtual interview, asks for writing sample and transcript. Actual interviews scheduled next. Interviewed with four people who were pleasant enough. Waited to hear back but had to email recruiter to check status.
Interview Questions:
How do you measure/ensure quality in your work?
Where do you see yourself in five years?
Describe a time when you had to work/perform with no guidance.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: Simple, straight forward, nice experience meeting team and learning about the company. Asked open-ended questions and were friendly. Had an interesting interview and thought the organization was a good fit
Interview Questions: Can not recall specific questions

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was quick and simple. Two weeks after I applied, I received an offer for a quick phone interview with a recruiter, which was as straightforward as phone screenings usually go. I was asked right after to provide a writing sample and two days later, I was called back for a second and final interview. This interview consisted of four back-to-back 30 min interviews with members of the team. It was more about getting to know you as a person, including your working style and ideal environment, so the mood felt comfortable. I was getting more excited for the position over time as well since I could sense the team's passion for the work. Quite a few questions overlapped and I received an informal offer later that day. The entire process took about a month.
Interview Questions: How do you manage multiple ongoing projects?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Chicago, IL) in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: Fifteen minute screening interview w/ Hiring Director (basic interview questions), then I was asked to send a writing sample, then an invitation to have 3 separate behavioral interviews with members of a research team.
Interview Questions: What is your experience with research? Explain a time where you had conflicting deadlines- which one did you handle first?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: Submitted application, then was contacted a month later. Had two phone screens, then spoke with hiring manager. Then was ghosted for a while then was finally offered the role. The interviews were straight forward. Questions about experience based on my resume and behavioral questions about group work ....etc.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your self, tell me about a research project you worked on and what was your role in it

title: Qualitative Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: The recruiter and the team were very responsive to my needs. I had another job offer that I needed to decide on and they transformed what was supposed to be a month-long interview process and fit it into a week's time.
Interview Questions:
What kind of data collection experience do you have in the field?
What experience do you have using qualitative research methods?

title: Research Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Lewiston, ME) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: Screening with a recruiter first, and then a 2.5 hour interview with various staff members. Questions ranged from behavioral to scenarios, as well as overviewing relevant experience. Was nice to get a feel for the staff and team members that I would be working with. The rigor of the interview depended on the person--for me, the principal researcher was very relaxed and I found that the other research analysts asked more difficult questions, but overall it was a positive experience.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you had to work as a team.

title: Junior Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Ottawa, ON) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: The application process was easy, after the submission of my application, I relatively quickly got an answer and an invitation to do further steps. That was a great chance and an advantage compared to competitors in a similar industry.
Interview Questions: E.g. Why did you apply for this position

title: Data Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: In person interview consisting of several individual interviews with different people, and also a presentation of my research similar to an academic job talk. Very extensive interview process, which allowed me to see if I was going to be a good fit for the company and allowed them to see if I was a good fit for the organization. In all, it was a long interview but was very helpful.
Interview Questions: Standard interview questions in the individual interviews.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: I had a series of short phone and video interviews with potential team members and managers. Questions ranged from standard behavioral questions to open ended discussion of my research interests.
Interview Questions: What are you hoping to gain from an internship at AIR?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Nov 2020
Interview Descriptions: Easy interview process, and I appreciated the quick and clear communication from the recruiter throughout. Applied and got invited to a 30 minute phone screener with an HR recruiter within a couple days. The interview asked pretty basic questions about my experience, interest in the role and that specific research area. Afterwards, I had to send a writing sample. Within a week I got invited to a 30 minute video interview with the  hiring manager, which was very casual and just asked me to elaborate specific experiences on my resume. Got back to me the next day with an invitation to a 1.5 hour interview with the larger group of researchers. It was basically 3 back to back 30-minute interviews with 3 separate researchers. Everyone was super nice and each interview more of a casual conversation about my interests and experiences. Got an offer the next day. Altogether took about a month. Was a great experience!
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in AIR and this department?

title: Quantitative Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: I was referred by a colleague.  The process took about a month (initial recruiter call, phone screen, all day on-site). I declined the offer because the salary offered was well below my current compensation and far outside the range initially quoted by the recruiter.
Interview Questions: The interviews were fairly casual discussions of my current and planned future research projects. Plan to describe your research in detail, provide details about your intended specialization at AIR, and articulate a vision for your area - where is the current need? Where are there gaps in knowledge? In one interview, I was also asked to think through a research strategy for an ongoing project.

title: Research Assistant - Quantitative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in May 2020
Interview Descriptions:
10-minute phone screen focused mainly on the "low pay" and how the hiring manager was "basically unwilling to even consider going above" a certain amount (their words). Did not spend much time discussing my background or what they were looking for. It was certainly off-putting, but I decided to go through with the process.

Communication prior to interview was minimal. Interviewed with three people for 30-minute segments each. 2/3 seemed very disorganized and misinformed, and it’s unclear whether HR even had a set interview procedure. It’s not unreasonable to expect that questions about the process/schedule prior to an interview would be appreciated and answered rather than ignored, forcing a prospective employee to go in unprepared.
Interview Questions: Screen-share with interviewer and write a function in R that will read all the column and row names in a data frame.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Mar 2020
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and was contacted about 2 weeks later for an initial phone screening.  The phone screening was straightforward, with the recruiter asking basic questions about my research experience and my interest in the role. At the end of our conversation, the recruiter asked me to send a writing sample and informed me I would hear about next steps within two weeks. After hearing nothing for three weeks (I figured with the pandemic, there might be some delay), I reached out and got no response. I tried to get an update a second time but still heard nothing from the recruiter or AIR, not even an automated reply. I understand COVID-19 has made things difficult for everyone, but they seem to be still hiring, so I was pretty frustrated as I  was told I would at least hear if I was rejected, which is much better than just being ignored.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Communications Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was long and tedious - I had 30 min sessions each with 7 mid- to high-level leaders in addition to my manager-to-be. But the worst was when, after being offered the job, I tried negotiating for a higher salary and they pulled the offer. Says a lot about the organization.
Interview Questions: What would you do to reach our target audience?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions:
Sent in application in January when I was living abroad, had initial phone screen I think a month later. Got an email that entire application process was put on hold. Re-applied when I returned to the US. HR rep was late to the phone screen but remembered me from the February call and passed me straight to the next round.

The second round was over video conference and was basically two back-to-back behavioral interview power hours. Spoke with HR for ten minutes, and then two groups of senior researchers asked questions off a script and you had to give short responses of how you would describe yourself / how you've acted in different scenarios. Pretty sure they had to rate the answers on a scale. There were a lot of questions and there were repeat questions across the two rounds, so if you mess up one there's opportunity to recover. Definitely some frankenstein monster cooked up by HR, but the interviewers were super friendly and eager to put me at ease. It was test of patience and of how well I could talk about and frame my experiences.

I didn't realize that the skype interview was the final round, so I was pleasantly surprised when they called back with an offer a week or two later.
Interview Questions: Would you describe yourself as a detail oriented or big picture person?

title: Assessment Reporting(Data QC) Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: Brief behavioral phone interview with HR recruiter. About a week later I had a 30 minute phone interview with the senior director for the reporting team which consisted of mostly behavioral questions.
Interview Questions: Tell me about any experience you have with Excel

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Nov 2019
Interview Descriptions:
The interview was conducted on Skype and was around 2 hours in total. However, those two hours were split into 30-45 minute segments where you talk either with the Senior Research Analyst, who would be your boss, or two separate teams of other research analysts, who would be your coworkers. 

A lot of the same questions were carried over from each interview time slot to the next.
Interview Questions: Do you like to work as part of a team or more as an individual?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: The HR called me about a week after I submitted my application. She scheduled an interview for me with a senior researcher. The interview was basic describing my previous work and experience. The salary they offered is way too low in the Bay area.
Interview Questions: Describe your previous work experience related to the hiring position.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: The first interview was a short 5-minute interview asking general questions and picking a time for the next interview. The next interview was 2-hours long and included 4 interviews. Most of the interview was scripted and if they felt like they wanted to know more about a particular answer, they would ask an of-scripted question.
Interview Questions: Behavioral questions about leadership, research, and teamwork style. What would you do if you had a project due in a week but your supervisor needed it tomorrow? How do you manage multiple projects at once? If you knew someone made a mistake analyzing a set of data, how would you go about problem-solving?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: It was pretty similar to other research assistant positions - first a qualifying phone interview with a rep from HR and then two weeks later I had a longer phone call with a project director before going in to one of the offices and having a series of five interviews. The questions weren't difficult, they really just wanted to get a sense of your skill and ability and why you want to work at AIR. In a way that makes the questions harder, because there really is no trick. But overall it was a pleasant experience and they were extremely thoughtful about keeping me updated at each stage of the process.
Interview Questions: Ask about a specific research experience involving whatever field this research assistantship is based in.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Aug 2019
Interview Descriptions: I got my 30 min phone interview about 2 weeks after I submitted the application. The phone interview was with the HR and  informative about the role and salary. I got an offer from a different place while I was waiting for the next round of interview and decided to withdraw my application.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in the position?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Aug 2019
Interview Descriptions: The process was very smooth, but not short. Had an HR phone screening a month after I applied. The HR person set up my phone interview with the hiring manager while we were still on the phone. Then a week later I got the in person interview that was 2.5 hours. Very quick turnaround to offering a job.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position?

title: Item Writer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: Began with HR phone screening, the notes from which were sent to the hiring manager. Three days later I was contacted by HR to schedule an in-person interview. I met with five people, three through a video chat and two in the DC office. I was there for just over 2.5 hours, which was really draining. Everyone was nice and engaged. Wasn't really asked any difficult questions. HR told me they should know the decision within 24 hours, which was true. Found out I was no longer being considered. The job description made it sound like it was an entry-level job, and one of the interviewers said training would be available. I guess they didn't want to work with me. Who knows. So many factors go into making the final decision. Also, I'm not sure why HR began the interview process by going in depth about the good benefits; it's a little cruel.
Interview Questions: How do you feel about being critiqued? Do you have any experience creating assessments? How would you go about selecting passages?

title: Research Assistant - Youth, Family, Community Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Austin, TX) in Jun 2019
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone interview with the HR Recruiter. I moved onto the the second round of interviews. I had two back-to-back interviews with 3 people in each interview. Each interview was 45 minutes. I prepared for the interview days in advance. I went over the requirements and how the aligned with my experiences and so much more. However, the questions asked were very data heavy (unexpected!). I took me a little longer to come up with responses since having strong analytical skill was not mentioned int he job description. I noticed one of the interviewers (in the first interview), who was a junior level staff, was smirking almost laughing. That completely threw me off! The second interview was a lot better. Overall, the first interview was completely unprofessional. Maybe just laugh at someone during a call. If you expect someone to have data software skills, then maybe mention that in the job description. Or how about maybe understand that it's an entry level role and those skills can be learned! I would suggest training junior level staff on how to conduct interviews (let go of your ego).
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself. Why AIR and why this research? Use of data.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted by the HR after submitting resume online. Had three rounds of interviews with five different people. Overall the interviews went pretty smoothly. The questions were pretty standard but we had to video calls, which I found a little bit confusing at first.
Interview Questions: Some statistics questions since my job is quantitative.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: My interview was over 4 hours long. I first spoke with HR, who gave me an overview of the workplace's policies. Then I interviewed with 2 more people who I would have been working for/with in person, and interviewed with another via Skype.  I followed up with the company via email thanking them. I never heard back from them- neither an offer nor a decline. Dissapointing to not even hear back.
Interview Questions: Do you have experience working with people who are not physically in the same place?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Boston, MA) in May 2019
Interview Descriptions:
I applied for the Research Assistant position available in the Boston office. I received an invitation to do an initial phone interview shortly after I applied and was then scheduled to have a follow-up phone interview with the principal researcher of the project.  After this interview, I received an email that same day requesting an in-person interview with AIR staff. This third round of interviews consisted of three, 30-minute virtual interviews with different staff involved in the project and one informational interview with a current in-office RA.

Despite sending multiple follow-up emails, I did not hear back from the recruiter for another three weeks. After three weeks, I received a reply from this recruiter letting me know that the team would be making a decision that day, and would get back to me later with the result. They then emailed later that evening informing me that the team wanted to extend me a job offer, and I would receive an offer letter in two days. 

It was the day after I had received this good news that I received an email from the recruiter informing me they were rescinding the job offer because the project funding had not been confirmed, and would get back to me if there was an update. Even after following up several times, I never heard back from the recruiter, nor anyone from AIR. Personally, I saw this as unprofessional and was very frustrated given that the interview process took 7 weeks and was three stages. My advice: be sure to ask about project funding when you interview with AIR for a project-specific RA position.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for AIR?

title: Research Support Staff Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions:
First there was a phone call with the recruiter, then a phone call with the hiring manager, and lastly, an in person interview with the hiring manager, the HM's supervisor, and HR.  Interview process moved quickly.

During my first call with the recruiter, I was told the job title and salary would be x.  When they made me an offer, it was for less money than originally offered, and for a lesser title, although the responsibilities would remain the same.

Also worth noting that the most senior level exec that I met has a very negative ethos - "I don't want any victims here."  A more positive perspective would have been "I want empowered people here".  Why are people thinking of themselves as victims?  And also, the lack of empathy being demonstrated by sneering at self-described "victims" is disconcerting. 

I very politely and promptly turned down the offer and didn't even get an acknowledgement from the recruiter.  I'm sure different departments operate differently -- consider yourself warned.

My recruiter and interviewers were all very, very nice and seemed genuinely interested in me and the work I'd done previously. My only complaint is the amount of time it took in between rounds and then to finally hear back (six weeks after last round).

title: Research Associate Interview

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Jun 2018
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted via email to schedule a phone interview with an HR person about a week after completing my online application. The phone interview was strange because it basically repeated questions that were asked on the online application. It was very brief, maybe 10 minutes long. At that point, I was told that I would be contacted if the Research team was interested in interviewing me. About a week after the phone interview, I was contacted to schedule another interview at the D.C. office (although I've heard from friends that there is an option to interview via video chat if you are not local). It was a long event, where I interviewed again with someone from HR and four people from the Research division. It was a good opportunity for me to paint a fuller picture of myself and make more of an impression than if I had a more traditional 30-45 minute interview with one person, and I think it helped me get the job. Everyone was very friendly, and they mostly asked background questions about my education and professional experience; there were very few behavioral questions. As I was interviewing for other positions at the time, the interview process helped me decide that AIR was the right fit for me. About two weeks after the in-person interview, I got a call from HR with an official offer. I was given a few days to give them my answer, which I took advantage of. While the salary is certainly competitive for an entry-level position, salary negotiation was not at all welcome. It was actually a little awkward how taken aback the HR person was when I attempted to negotiate. I assumed that salary negotiation was expected; even though they were unable to negotiate, they could have been more polite/understanding in refusing the negotiation. I say this because salary negotiation, while a difficult skill, is important particularly when it comes to pay equity and I believe it is a practice that should be much more openly discussed. All told, the hiring process took about a month and a half, so it wasn't super speedy but it was much faster than other organizations I applied to.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your research experience.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Mar 2018
Interview Descriptions:
I submitted my application online and a recruiter called me to schedule a phone interview with a senior member of the team. The phone interview lasted about an hour and was very technical due to the technical nature of this position. Following the phone interview, I was asked to complete a coding assessment within 3 days. About two weeks after I submitted the assessment, the recruiter reached out to schedule an in-person interview with the entire team at the headquarter in DC. The half-day interview took about 3 hours, with half-hour time slots with different team members, from senior level to associate level. 

I would say that the phone interview and the coding assessment were definitely okay overall, but the in-person interview was a bit confusing and also very stressful, because of the various different (even conflicting) expectations from different members of the team about this position. I was asked a lot of technical questions for which one of the interviewers was expecting a certain fixed answer, and the in-person interview was actually different than I had imagined. I was also asked questions about experience and qualifications that were not included in the job description, and it seems that the interviewers did not quite get on the same page about what to expect about this role. Overall, I would say that this entire interview process was very stressful and mildly unpleasant.
Interview Questions: How do you transform a data set given the distribution of the data.

title: ELearning & Training Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process included an initial phone screen with HR, followed by a 30 minute phone interview with the hiring manager.  After those interviews, I interviewed in person two days later: 4, 30-minute interviews back to back and a writing test. After that the hiring manager wanted to do another 30 min phone interview the following week. The hiring manager made me a verbal offer in the last phone meeting, discussed my salary expectations which were on target with hers, discussed a starting date and that they wanted to switch the role to a contract position for the first 3 months, to which I agreed. She told me she'd have the HR personnel follow up with me and that she was excited to have me come aboard. I waited a week for HR to contact and then followed up. The HR person indicated that the hiring manager had not contacted her with offer information for me and that the hiring manager still wanted to interview other candidates and would make a decision and notify me on a specific date in a week. A week later the HR person told me I was still under consideration but they would be pushing their decision back by another week. That week came and went and I was not notified either way. 

In all, aside from my meetings with HR and the four individuals, the interview process was disorganized. Each thirty minute interview was rushed and didn't offer enough time to have reasonable discussions, but each person I met with still tried to have a good interview meeting despite the rush. Also the hiring manager was rushed in all three of the meetings I had with her and obviously it left a bad taste to be offered the job by the hiring manager and then to not even be directly told that the offer is being rescinded or rethought or why. She asked me to prepare some materials for the interview, which I did and then apparently did not remember what materials she had asked for also didn't have time to look at them. 

The hiring managers at this firm need additional training from HR on how to conduct interviews well: how long a quality interview should be, how to prepare yourself and questions prior to an interview in order to gather the data you need to make a decision in an organized and timely manner and of course what questions you can legally ask candidates so as not to open the company up to any legal exposure. No one took notes in any of minutes and essentially just asked me questions off the cuff.

I've known other employers who work from a list of set questions when interviewing multiple candidates to ensure equitable comparison, to ensure of course notes are taken rather than working from memory to make a hiring decision and to ensure they don't discuss things they shouldn't with candidates.

Also be considerate of the effort candidates put into in their job search and make sure that hiring managers have the time to evaluate candidates, their work and respond in a reasonable timeframe or certainly in the time frame you commit to respond in.
Interview Questions:
General interview questions about my professional background and interest in the role and the company. However the hiring manager, a Vice President, did ask me an illegal question regarding what did my spouse do for a living I'm assuming so she could get a sense of how long did I plan to be living in the area. And another interviewer inadvertently asked me if had children but did take back the question after they, I believe, realized, it was inappropriate for an interview

Where do I see myself in five years?

title: Science Assessment Item Writer Interview

Interview Descriptions: The interview process at AIR is as disorganized as the organization itself. I applied at the beginning of November, had a phone screen two weeks later, a phone interview with the hiring manager two weeks later, then a test & Skype interview two weeks after that, and I still have never been informed where my candidacy stands (3 months later). I checked in two weeks after my Skype interview and they told me a decision had not yet been made. I have not heard from them since. The phone screen was pretty standard and the recruiter very nice. The phone interview was the total opposite, the woman on the other end seemed uninterested in talking to me and wanted me to design questions on the spot for topics I had not studied since high school. The Skype interview was better, but a lot of the people told me just how disorganized and chaotic their organization was. While I appreciated their honesty, this may not be the best way to sell your organization to a potential employee. Overall, even if they had offered me a position, I would have politely declined because it was evident there are a lot of problems and chaos in the assessment department. This is also clear reading employees reviews.

title: Test Developer Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions: Was contacted by third party recruiter for temporary position. Setup interview within 1 week. Interview was over phone with 3 senior test developers. Was given job offer within 1 week of interview.
Interview Questions: Do you have any programming knowledge?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions: It took 3 months. The first round interview was a phone interview asking behavioral questions. The second round was a go-to-meeting interview with two senior researchers and they ask a lot about my previous experience and statistical background.
Interview Questions: Tell me about research projects you have previously done.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and a few days later received the HR's email scheduling an initial telephone screening. It was quite standard and lasted 10-15 minutes collecting basic information, at the end of the call the HR asked me to submit a set of my independent writing samples in order to be considered for the second round of interview. I emailed her three writing samples of mine and waited for about 2 weeks before they further contacted me to schedule the second phone interview with the hiring manager. The second interview lasted for about 30 minutes asking for experience in relevant skills required by the position. It was a pleasant conversation and the hiring manager was friendly and courteous. 3 days later I was informed to confirm with a date for an onsite interview. Flight and accommodation were both taken care of by AIR, which was good. The onsite interview was 3-hour long talking with 6 interviewers with a 2-interview panel in each hour, starting from those who are in the position I applied for to senior fellows. 3 of them were in the DC office, so it was part remote. All of them were friendly and courteous and asked questions basically related to my research experience and particular skills with very few behavioral questions as I remember. The last hour with two senior fellows was a lot more technical and difficult than with the previous two panels. I gave half-baked answers to two questions in this round. Overall it was a positive experience meeting nice people, and the entire process was very professional. Two weeks later I was informed that they just chose someone else.
Interview Questions: How could you ensure the validity of data collected from surveys?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions:
Apply, Hr phone screen, phone call with manager, interviews either onsite or via video,  job offer

Video interview felt long. Interviewed with 2 people at a time for an hour. Did two sessions of that then one final one with one person for 30 min.
Interview Questions: Software capabilities and how and when I have used them

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: Assessment,Interview and Final Assessment on Sql Scripting questions.Mostly on Sql and the scripting.There will be conceptual and also scripting questions on various requirements.Should have good knowledge working on Sql.Assessment,Interview and Final Assessment on Sql Scripting questions.Mostly on Sql and the scripting.There will be conceptual and also scripting questions on various requirements.Should have good knowledge working on Sql
Interview Questions: Pivot tables

title: Principal Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Dec 2016
Interview Descriptions: Phone screening with the recruiter followed by phone interview with two senior software engineering managers. They mainly asked theoretical technical questions and had specific answer in mind. Any alternative valid options were not taken seriously. It was obvious that the interviewers were not able to evaluate analytical problem solving creative thinks skills.
Interview Questions: What is the minimum and maximum number of entries in a JOIN operation?

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: Applied online and received a call after 2 weeks from a recruiter to set up a 15 min phone interview. That went well, the recruiter was very friendly and professional. The recruiter then set up a 30 min phone interview with the hiring managers (researchers ) for the following day which was a total joke. There  was some awkward silence and over all the interaction was very dull and unattractive. As they went along with explaining the position, I started to lose interest with the position and the people I may be working with.
Interview Questions: Basic interview  questions. Why did you choose AIR and the position etc

title: Psychometric Support/Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Sept 2016
Interview Descriptions:
The total process once I received the first call from the recruiter took about three weeks, it was very quick. I applied online through Indeed and got a random call a few weeks later asking me to do a brief, easy phone screening. The next step was a 30 minute phone interview which was also very easy and straightforward, asking mostly about my interest in the position and my research experience.
The final step is a 3 hour in-person interview; since I was traveling out of the country we scheduled a skype interview, and I spoke with 6 different individuals for 30 minutes at a time. Fairly straightforward and mostly similar, asking me mostly about my research experience, why I was interested in working for AIR, and my future plans etc. 
I found out a week later I got the offer.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your undergraduate research experience and talk a little about working independently and with others

title: Network Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Sept 2016
Interview Descriptions: a recruited contacted me and scheduled a 30 minute interview with the IT director. basic questions mostly on my background and on the job description. passed that and got another 30 minute technical interview. was good and got a third face to face interview with 6 people who i work with each with 30 minutes.
Interview Questions: what is your interest in the future ?

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: The process was long and confusing. I did 3 phone interviews, one all day interview where I had to give a "job-talk" similar to a talk given for an academic job and a second 2 hour interview. After that I waited for more than 2 months for a decision. The whole process took longer than a federal job.
Interview Questions: Statistical methods?

title: Test Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: The recruiter was friendly. The next round..the hiring manager was condescending and dismissive before I even got a chance to explain or sell myself. She acted as if she was annoyed she had to speak to me...100% rude. Additionally   she immediately yawned and sighed after i just answered hello.
Interview Questions: Why do you consider your nonpaid graduate research relevant?

title: Item Writer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Jun 2016
Interview Descriptions: Three interviews, one face to face, two by phone. They had an editing task where they had random writing samples which were to be edited. The expectation was that the item writer knows obscure science facts by rote.
Interview Questions: They asked how good I was with getting critiqued.

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Chicago, IL) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: Received a call from HR to set up a phone interview with a lead software developer on the team. When talking to the developer we discussed class work and went over my resume.  About half way thought the interview he called me (female) sweetheart. While the interview went okay, I was not planning on taking the job after that.
Interview Questions: What is the difference between a stack and a queue

title: Test Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: Screening interview with HR, phone interview with manager, flew me out for third interview during which time I took a one hour test and had a half hour interview with 5 different team members. It was almost s 4 hour process.
Interview Questions: Tell me more about your experience.

title: Item Writer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: American Institutes for Research offered me an interview after I submitted an online application. They flew me out to DC (even though I would be working in Chicago) for an extensive interview process that involved a skills assessment in which I was given 30 minutes or so to perform specific job-related tasks such as writing content. Then, I had six different one-on-one interviews with people of various rankings within the organization, including the vice president, the director, and a staff manager.
Interview Questions: They asked me to explain in detail my process for writing assessment items.

title: Psychometric Support/Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions:
There were three interviews in total. First a brief (15 min) phone interview, then a 30 minute phone interview the following week, followed finally by a 3 hour interview on sight.

The first interview was pretty standard (why are you interested in working here, etc.); the second was more about my experience; and the third was fairly similar to the second but on sight and with more people.
Interview Questions: What are your research interests?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions: The recurter called and told me the description of the job. Made an appointment for a phone interview. On the phone interview day nothing hard was asked... The interviewer mainly described the job and asked if that is something I would be interested in
Interview Questions: They just want to know if what they are offering you is something that you would interested in doing

title: Linux Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Washington, DC) in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions:
I have done many phone interviews, but nothing has been as odd as my experiences with AIR.  First call was a quick series of technical questions that were almost unrelated to the job offered.  The questions were programming oriented questions for a Linux systems administrator job.  I thought that was the end of it and was sent a email stating I was not selected.  Shortly after I was emailed again asking for a second phone interview.  They canceled that one at the last minute.  It was rescheduled and we started talking about my past experience.  Mid way though me talking they said it was 'not a match' as they were looking for 10-15 years of experience in the Linux systems administration field and I had about seven.  

I hear that AIR is a great place to work but they have a pretty unusual set of gatekeepers there.
Interview Questions: Unrelated to the job being offered.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Chicago, IL) in Mar 2016
Interview Descriptions: very positive interview process overall. The lady who contacted me was friendly and explained the organization completely. They seem like a solid company really focused on the benefit of supporting schools and educators.
Interview Questions: Given all of the sources of information circulating on the internet, how do you consider which sources to site and which to leave out?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: Submitted an application online, didn't hear back right away.  Several weeks later I get a call from someone in HR looking to do a phone interview on the spot.  They called at 1pm while I was at work and I didn't pick up the phone.  Returned their call and left a message with some times that would work for me and directed them to email me if they'd like an alternate time.  No response.  2 days later the same woman calls again at 10am (not one of my suggested times).  I call back and get a voicemail - leave a nearly identical message to the 1st.  This goes on for a week or so, back and forth.  I stopped trying to call back - if they can't be bothered to schedule something in advance or communicate with applicants in a reasonable way I can only imagine how awful it must be to actually work there.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Research Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Institutes for Research
Interview Descriptions: Preliminary phone interview. Followed by an in person interview. Was never able to schedule the in-person interview as they kept cancelling and rescheduling with little notice. As I had several job interviews occurring at the same time, after the third cancelling of my in-person interview, I decided to decline the offer to come in and pursue several other opportunities that were moving along more quickly.
Interview Questions: What kind of research have you done?

title: Network Support Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at American Institutes for Research (Reston, VA) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions:
recieved a call from the recruiter.
we had a phone interview
took a behaviour test.
skype interview

medium size room 2-3 managers from their team
Interviewed
